text: Louise Burns was in clarity's yesterday
when her daughter Isadora became hungry
so she did the obvious thing very
discreetly I started to feed her and
pretty much as soon as that had happened
somebody came over the waiter came over
and he knelt down beside me and said
very politely excuse me about policy at
Claridge's is that we asked
breastfeeding mothers to cover up and my
initial reaction was to burst into tears
and I was just I felt completely
humiliated and by the request I think I
felt that I was doing something that was
right and natural and the best thing for
my baby I've been very discreet and and
considerate of other guests in the hotel
and I felt that it was quite an
upsetting thing to ask me to do in a
statement Claridge's told us we are
saddened to see what is being discussed
and we feel we need to clarify that
breastfeeding is embraced at Claridge's
all we ask is that mothers are discreet
towards other guests under the Equality
Act 2010 it's sex discrimination to
treat a woman unfavorably because she's
breastfeeding it means women can't be
asked to stop breastfeeding or service
be refused
Louise Burns says she's amazed at the
support she's received since tweeting
about her experience but she says she
won't be returning to Claridge's
Victoria Hollins BBC London News
